title: An Explicit Sixth Order Runge-Kutta Method for Simple Lawson Integration
summary: Explicit Runge-Kutta schemes become impractical when a stiff linear operator is present in the dynamics. This failure mode is quite common in numerical simulations of fluids and plasmas. Lawson proposed Generalized Runge-Kutta Processes for stiff problems in 1967, in which the stiff linear operator is treated fully implicitly via matrix exponentiation. Any Runge-Kutta scheme induces valid Lawson integration, but a scheme is exceptionally simple to implement if the abscissa $c_i$ are ordered and equally spaced. Classical RK4 satisfies this requirement, but it is difficult to derive efficient higher order schemes with this constraint. Here I present an explicit sixth order method identified with Newton-Raphson iteration that provides simple Lawson integration.

AI.tldr: A 6th-order explicit Runge-Kutta method with ordered, equally-spaced abscissae for efficient Lawson integration of stiff problems
AI.motivation: Standard explicit Runge-Kutta schemes fail for stiff linear operators common in fluid and plasma simulations. Lawson integration treats stiff operators implicitly via matrix exponentiation, but requires ordered, equally-spaced abscissae for simple implementation.
AI.method: Developed an explicit sixth-order Runge-Kutta method with ordered, equally-spaced abscissae using Newton-Raphson iteration, enabling simple Lawson integration for stiff problems.
AI.result: Identified a valid sixth-order explicit Runge-Kutta scheme that satisfies the Lawson integration requirements (ordered, equally-spaced abscissae), overcoming the difficulty of deriving efficient higher-order methods with these constraints.
AI.conclusion: The presented sixth-order method enables simple and efficient Lawson integration for stiff problems involving linear operators, extending beyond classical RK4 to higher-order accuracy while maintaining implementation simplicity.

title: Beyond Low Rank: Fast Low-Rank + Diagonal Decomposition with a Spectral Approach
summary: Low-rank plus diagonal (LRPD) decompositions provide a powerful structural model for large covariance matrices, simultaneously capturing global shared factors and localized corrections that arise in covariance estimation, factor analysis, and large-scale kernel learning. We introduce an alternating low-rank then diagonal (Alt) algorithm that provably reduces approximation error and significantly outperforms gradient descent while remaining cheaper than majorization-minimization methods~\cite{sun2016majorization}. To scale to large matrices, we develop a randomized LRPD variant that combines fixed-rank Nystrom sketching~\cite{tropp2017fixed} for the low-rank component with Diag++ stochastic diagonal estimation~\cite{baston2022stochastic}. This hybrid algorithm achieves machine precision decomposition error using a number of matrix-vector products far smaller than the ambient dimension, and comes with rigorous non-asymptotic error bounds. On synthetic data, it exactly recovers LRPD structured matrices with high efficiency, and on real-world S&P 500 stock return covariances, where the spectrum decays slowly and strong sector structure exists, it achieves substantially lower error than pure low-rank approximations.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces efficient algorithms for Low-rank plus diagonal (LRPD) covariance matrix decompositions, combining alternating optimization with randomized sketching for scalable, high-precision estimation.
AI.motivation: LRPD decompositions are powerful for modeling large covariance matrices in applications like factor analysis and kernel learning, but existing methods are computationally expensive or inefficient for large-scale problems.
AI.method: Proposes alternating low-rank then diagonal (Alt) algorithm and a randomized LRPD variant combining fixed-rank Nystrom sketching for low-rank component with Diag++ stochastic diagonal estimation.
AI.result: The hybrid algorithm achieves machine precision decomposition error with far fewer matrix-vector products than ambient dimension, exactly recovers LRPD structured matrices on synthetic data, and outperforms pure low-rank approximations on real-world S&P 500 stock return covariances.
AI.conclusion: The proposed algorithms provide efficient, scalable solutions for LRPD covariance decomposition with rigorous error bounds, significantly improving over existing methods for both synthetic and real-world financial data.

title: Long-time stability and convergence analysis of an IMEX BDF3 scheme for 2-D incompressible Navier-Stokes equation
summary: High-order time-stepping schemes are crucial for simulating incompressible fluid flows due to their ability to capture complex turbulent behavior and unsteady motion. In this work, we propose a third-order accurate numerical scheme for the two-dimensional incompressible Navier-Stokes equation. Spatial and temporal discretization is achieved using Fourier pseudo-spectral approximation and the BDF3 stencil, combined with the Adams-Bashforth extrapolation for the nonlinear convection term, resulting in a semi-implicit, fully discrete formulation. This approach requires solving only a single Poisson-like equation per time step while maintaining the desired temporal accuracy. Classical numerical experiments demonstrate the advantage of our scheme in terms of permissible time step sizes. Moreover, we establish uniform-in-time bounds for the vorticity in both $L^2$ and higher-order $H^m$ norms ($m \geq 1$), provided the time step is sufficiently small. These bounds, in turn, facilitate the derivation of optimal convergence rates.

AI.tldr: Third-order accurate scheme for 2D incompressible Navier-Stokes using Fourier pseudo-spectral spatial discretization, BDF3 temporal discretization, and Adams-Bashforth extrapolation for nonlinear terms, requiring only one Poisson-like equation per time step.
AI.motivation: High-order time-stepping schemes are essential for accurately simulating complex turbulent behavior and unsteady motion in incompressible fluid flows, but need to balance accuracy with computational efficiency.
AI.method: Combines Fourier pseudo-spectral approximation for spatial discretization with BDF3 (third-order backward differentiation formula) for temporal discretization. Uses Adams-Bashforth extrapolation for the nonlinear convection term, resulting in a semi-implicit formulation that requires solving only one Poisson-like equation per time step.
AI.result: The scheme demonstrates advantages in permissible time step sizes through classical numerical experiments. The authors establish uniform-in-time bounds for vorticity in both L² and higher-order Hᵐ norms (m ≥ 1) when the time step is sufficiently small, which enables derivation of optimal convergence rates.
AI.conclusion: The proposed third-order scheme provides an efficient and accurate approach for simulating 2D incompressible Navier-Stokes equations, balancing computational efficiency (single Poisson solve per step) with high temporal accuracy and rigorous mathematical analysis of stability and convergence.

title: Sobolev Algorithm for Local Smoothness Analysis (SALSA) via Sharp Direct and Inverse Statements
summary: We extend sharp direct and inverse approximation statements for kernel-based methods for finitely smooth kernels, i.e. those whose native spaces are norm-equivalent to Sobolev spaces. In particular, our inverse results are now formulated for a broad class of approximation schemes beyond interpolation, extending existing theory. Building on these results, we propose a novel Sobolev Algorithm for Local Smoothness Analysis (SALSA) for detecting local smoothness properties of target data, including their degree of smoothness and non-smoothness. The method is rigorously grounded based on the sharp direct and inverse statements. Numerical experiments in various settings highlight the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

AI.tldr: Extends sharp direct/inverse approximation theory for kernel methods, proposes SALSA algorithm for local smoothness analysis, validated numerically.
AI.motivation: To extend existing approximation theory for finitely smooth kernels to broader approximation schemes beyond interpolation, and to develop a practical algorithm for detecting local smoothness properties of target data.
AI.method: Extends sharp direct and inverse approximation statements for kernel-based methods with finitely smooth kernels. Proposes Sobolev Algorithm for Local Smoothness Analysis (SALSA) based on these theoretical results for detecting local smoothness properties including degree of smoothness and non-smoothness.
AI.result: Theoretical extension of approximation theory to broader class of approximation schemes, and development of SALSA algorithm that is rigorously grounded in the sharp direct/inverse statements. Numerical experiments demonstrate effectiveness in various settings.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully extends approximation theory for kernel methods and proposes a novel, theoretically grounded algorithm for local smoothness analysis that shows practical effectiveness in numerical experiments.

title: On Energy-Dependent Neutron Diffusion
summary:
While the energy-dependent neutron diffusion equation is widely employed in nuclear engineering, its status as an approximation to the transport equation is not yet completely understood, and several different approximations are in use to determine the diffusion coefficients. Past work on the theory underlying the diffusion approximation has often made use of asymptotic arguments; in the energy-dependent case, however, papers have appeared that differ substantially in their findings. Here we present a formal asymptotic derivation of the multigroup diffusion equation which addresses these differences, along with the varying and sometimes physically stringent assumptions employed in these works.
  Further, we show a way to exactly invert the relationship between flux and current in the P1 approximation, giving a matricial expression for the multigroup diffusion coefficient which is formally exact, has clear physical meaning, and which can be easily computed to arbitrary precision on the basis of cross-section data already produced by lattice calculations. The resulting 2-group diffusion coefficient for an infinite medium of hydrogen is calculated with Monte Carlo, and compared to the those deriving from the Cumulative Migration Method and from the out-scatter approximation.

AI.tldr: Formal asymptotic derivation of multigroup diffusion equation addressing conflicting literature, plus exact inversion of flux-current relationship in P1 approximation yielding physically meaningful diffusion coefficients computable from lattice data.
AI.motivation: The energy-dependent neutron diffusion equation is widely used but its theoretical foundation as an approximation to transport equation is not fully understood, with conflicting results in literature and various approximations for diffusion coefficients.
AI.method: 1) Formal asymptotic derivation of multigroup diffusion equation addressing differences in literature. 2) Exact inversion of flux-current relationship in P1 approximation yielding matricial expression for multigroup diffusion coefficients computable from cross-section data.
AI.result: Derived exact expression for multigroup diffusion coefficients with clear physical meaning, computable to arbitrary precision from lattice calculation data. Calculated 2-group diffusion coefficient for infinite hydrogen medium using Monte Carlo and compared with Cumulative Migration Method and out-scatter approximation.
AI.conclusion: Provides rigorous theoretical foundation for multigroup diffusion approximation with exact diffusion coefficient formulation that can be computed directly from available cross-section data, resolving inconsistencies in previous literature.

title: On the existence of solutions to the multi-species Landau equation
summary: We consider the spatially homogeneous Landau equation for multiple species with different masses. As in the single-species case, the singularity of the collision operator is determined by a parameter $γ\in [-3,1]$, where $γ= -3$ corresponds to Coulomb interactions. We prove that if $γ\geq -\sqrt{8}$ in the cross-interaction operators, then there exists a natural multi-species generalization of the Fisher information which is a Lyapunov functional for the multi-species Landau system. On the other hand, we give a counterexample showing that the Fisher information is in general no longer a Lyapunov functional below the threshold $(γ< - \sqrt{8})$ for the two-species system if one species has infinite mass. However, we are able to provide a new method to show global well-posedness, by constructing a different Lyapunov functional based on the spherical Fisher information.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes the multi-species Landau equation, showing that a natural generalization of Fisher information serves as a Lyapunov functional for γ ≥ -√8, but fails below this threshold, requiring a new approach using spherical Fisher information for global well-posedness.
AI.motivation: To understand the behavior of the multi-species Landau equation with different masses, particularly the role of Fisher information as a Lyapunov functional across different interaction strengths (γ parameter), and to address cases where the standard approach fails.
AI.method: The authors prove that for γ ≥ -√8, a natural multi-species generalization of Fisher information works as a Lyapunov functional. For γ < -√8, they construct a counterexample showing Fisher information fails, then develop a new method using spherical Fisher information to establish global well-posedness.
AI.result: Established threshold γ = -√8 as critical point: above this, standard Fisher information generalization works; below it, Fisher information fails as Lyapunov functional. Successfully proved global well-posedness using spherical Fisher information approach.
AI.conclusion: The multi-species Landau equation has a critical threshold at γ = -√8 for the applicability of Fisher information as Lyapunov functional. For stronger singularities (γ < -√8), a modified approach using spherical Fisher information is necessary and effective for establishing global well-posedness.

title: Asymptotic state of nonlinear Landau damping in one-dimensional plasma
summary: In this work, the asymptotic state of nonlinear Landau damping in one-dimensional plasma has been examined using a quasi-linear model and a second-order symplectic integrator. The dispersion relation of the plateau distribution function for the steady-state solution of the quasi-linear mode is extended to the complex plane and compared with the nonlinear simulation. We determine that the asymptotic state of the collisionless plasma is a multi-wave BGK structure. This structure is characterized by multiple vortices in phase space, which correspond to distinct peaks in the frequency-wavenumber (ω, k) spectrum of the electric field

AI.tldr: Nonlinear Landau damping in 1D plasma leads to multi-wave BGK structures with phase-space vortices, confirmed by quasi-linear theory and symplectic simulations.
AI.motivation: To understand the asymptotic state of nonlinear Landau damping in collisionless plasmas, which remains an important open question in plasma physics.
AI.method: Used quasi-linear model with second-order symplectic integrator, extended dispersion relation of plateau distribution to complex plane, compared with nonlinear simulations.
AI.result: The asymptotic state is a multi-wave BGK structure characterized by multiple vortices in phase space, corresponding to distinct peaks in the (ω, k) spectrum of electric field.
AI.conclusion: Nonlinear Landau damping in collisionless plasma evolves into multi-wave BGK structures rather than complete damping, with phase-space vortices persisting as the final state.

title: A cut finite element method for the Biot system of poroelasticity
summary: We propose a novel cut finite element method for the numerical solution of the Biot system of poroelasticity. The Biot system couples elastic deformation of a porous solid with viscous fluid flow and commonly arises on domains with complex geometries that make high-quality volumetric meshing challenging. To address this issue, we employ the cut finite element framework, where the domain boundary is represented independently of the background mesh, which significantly simplifies the meshing process. Our approach builds upon a parameter robust total pressure formulation of the Biot system, which we combine with the cut finite element method to develop a geometrically robust solution scheme, while preserving the parameter robustness. A key ingredient in the theoretical analysis is a modified inf-sup condition which also holds for mixed boundary conditions, leading to stability and optimal error estimates for the proposed formulation. Finally, we provide numerical evidence demonstrating the theoretical properties of the method and showcasing its capabilities by solving the Biot system on a realistic brain geometry.

AI.tldr: A cut finite element method for the Biot poroelasticity system that handles complex geometries by decoupling domain boundaries from background meshing, while maintaining parameter robustness through a total pressure formulation.
AI.motivation: The Biot system models porous media with fluid-structure interaction but often involves complex geometries that make traditional volumetric meshing difficult and time-consuming. There's a need for methods that simplify meshing while maintaining numerical robustness.
AI.method: Combines cut finite element method (where domain boundaries are represented independently of background mesh) with a parameter-robust total pressure formulation of the Biot system. Uses a modified inf-sup condition to handle mixed boundary conditions.
AI.result: Develops a geometrically robust solution scheme that preserves parameter robustness. Provides stability and optimal error estimates. Numerical experiments demonstrate theoretical properties and show capability to solve Biot system on realistic brain geometry.
AI.conclusion: The proposed cut finite element method successfully addresses meshing challenges for complex geometries in poroelasticity problems while maintaining numerical robustness and accuracy, making it suitable for realistic applications like brain modeling.

title: Quantitative phase nano-imaging with a laboratory source
summary: Investigating the structure of matter at the nanoscale non destructively is a key capability enabled by X-ray imaging. One of the most powerful nano-imaging methods is X-ray ptychography, a coherent diffraction imaging technique that has become the go-to method at synchrotron facilities for applications ranging from brain imaging to battery materials. However, the requirements in terms of X-ray beam quality have limited its use to large synchrotron facilities and, to date, only one attempt has been made to translate the technique to a small-scale laboratory. To unleash the power of this technique to the broad user community of laboratory X-ray sources, there are outstanding questions to answer including whether the quantitativeness of the information is preserved in a laboratory despite the drastic decrease in X-ray flux of several orders of magnitude, with respect to synchrotron instruments. In this study not only we demonstrate that the quantitativeness of X-ray ptychography is preserved in a laboratory setting, but we also apply the method to the imaging of a brain tissue phantom. Finally, we describe the current challenges and limitations, and we set the basis for further development and future directions of quantitative nano-imaging with laboratory X-ray sources.

AI.tldr: X-ray ptychography can work in lab settings with preserved quantitativeness, enabling nano-imaging of brain tissue phantoms despite lower flux.
AI.motivation: X-ray ptychography is powerful but limited to synchrotrons; needs translation to lab sources for broader accessibility despite flux challenges.
AI.method: Demonstrated X-ray ptychography in laboratory setting, applied to brain tissue phantom imaging, assessed quantitativeness preservation.
AI.result: Quantitativeness of X-ray ptychography is preserved in laboratory despite orders of magnitude lower X-ray flux compared to synchrotrons.
AI.conclusion: Lab X-ray ptychography is feasible and quantitative, enabling nano-imaging applications; outlines challenges and future development directions.

title: Constant potentials do not minimise the fundamental gap on convex domains in hyperbolic space
summary: We show that for every $n \geq 2$ and $D > 0$ there exist a convex domain $Ω\subseteq \mathbb H^n$ with diameter $D$ and a convex potential $V$ on $Ω$ such that the fundamental gap of the operator $-Δ+V$ is strictly smaller than the fundamental gap of $-Δ$. In comparison to previous work, this result requires more refined control of the eigenfunctions.

AI.tldr: The paper shows that for any dimension n≥2 and diameter D>0, there exists a convex domain Ω in hyperbolic space with diameter D and a convex potential V such that the fundamental gap of -Δ+V is strictly smaller than that of -Δ.
AI.motivation: To investigate how adding a convex potential affects the fundamental gap (difference between first two eigenvalues) of the Laplace operator on convex domains in hyperbolic space, particularly whether it can decrease the gap compared to the pure Laplacian case.
AI.method: The authors construct specific convex domains Ω in hyperbolic space H^n with given diameter D, and convex potentials V on these domains. They achieve refined control over eigenfunctions to demonstrate the gap reduction phenomenon.
AI.result: For every n≥2 and D>0, there exists a convex domain Ω⊆H^n with diameter D and convex potential V such that the fundamental gap of -Δ+V is strictly smaller than the fundamental gap of -Δ.
AI.conclusion: Adding a convex potential can actually decrease the fundamental gap of the Laplace operator on convex domains in hyperbolic space, which contrasts with Euclidean space results and requires more refined eigenfunction analysis.

title: Influence of plasma shaping on the parity of core-localized toroidal Alfvén eigenmode in an advanced tokamak configuration
summary: Toroidal Alfvén eigenmodes (TAEs) and energetic particle modes (EPMs) can both be excited by energetic particles from auxiliary heating and fusion-born alpha particles in a tokamak. Using the hybrid kinetic-MHD model implemented in the NIMROD code, the excitation of these modes and their properties are investigated in an advanced tokamak configuration with reversed magnetic shear in the core region. The dominant TAE/EPM is found to exhibit odd parity with an anti-ballooning structure when the plasma has elongated, non-circular two-dimensional shaping. As the plasma shaping becomes more circular with reduced elongation, the mode parity undergoes a transition to even parity accompanied by a ballooning structure. These results may help explain the dominant parity of TAE/EPMs observed in advanced tokamak configurations with different plasma shaping.

AI.tldr: TAE/EPM parity transitions from odd to even as plasma shaping changes from elongated to circular in reversed-shear tokamaks.
AI.motivation: To understand how plasma shaping affects the parity and structure of Toroidal Alfvén eigenmodes and energetic particle modes in advanced tokamak configurations with reversed magnetic shear, which is important for predicting and controlling these instabilities in fusion devices.
AI.method: Using the hybrid kinetic-MHD model implemented in the NIMROD code to simulate excitation and properties of TAE/EPMs in an advanced tokamak configuration with reversed magnetic shear, analyzing mode parity and structure under different plasma shaping conditions.
AI.result: TAE/EPMs exhibit odd parity with anti-ballooning structure in elongated, non-circular plasma shaping, but transition to even parity with ballooning structure as plasma becomes more circular with reduced elongation.
AI.conclusion: Plasma shaping significantly influences TAE/EPM parity and structure, providing insights to explain observed mode characteristics in advanced tokamak configurations with different shaping profiles.

title: Comparison of two statistical image reconstruction algorithms for quantitative assessment of pathological lesions using gamma emission tomography
comment: 20 pages, in Russian language, 6 figures, keywords: single-photon emission computed tomography, image reconstruction algorithms, OSEM, MAP-Ent, regularization, quantitative assessment
summary: This study compares two statistical approaches to image reconstruction in single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT). We evaluated the widely used Ordered Subset Expectation Maximization (OSEM) algorithm and the newer Maximum a Posteriori approach with Entropy prior (MAP-Ent) approach in the context of quantifying radiopharmaceutical uptake in pathological lesions. Numerical experiments were performed using a digital twin of the standardized NEMA IEC phantom, which contains six spheres of varying diameters to simulate lesions. Quantitative accuracy was assessed using the maximum recovery coefficient (RCmax), defined as the ratio of the reconstructed maximum activity to the true value. The study shows that OSEM exhibits unstable convergence during iterations, leading to noise and edge artifacts in lesion images. Post-filtering stabilizes the reconstruction and ensures convergence, producing RCmax-size curves that could be used as correction factors in clinical evaluations. However, this approach significantly underestimates uptake in small lesions and may even lead to the complete loss of small lesions on reconstructed images. In contrast, MAP-Ent demonstrates fundamentally different behavior: it achieves stable convergence and preserves quantitative accuracy without post-filtering, while maintaining the contrast of even the smallest lesions. However, the iteration number at which accurate reconstruction is achieved depends strongly on the choice of a single global regularization parameter, which limits optimal performance across lesions of different sizes. These results demonstrate the need for locally adaptive regularization in MAP-Ent to improve quantitative accuracy in lesion reconstruction.

AI.tldr: Comparison of OSEM vs MAP-Ent for SPECT lesion quantification shows OSEM requires post-filtering but loses small lesions, while MAP-Ent preserves accuracy but needs adaptive regularization.
AI.motivation: To compare two statistical reconstruction approaches (OSEM and MAP-Ent) for quantifying radiopharmaceutical uptake in SPECT lesions, addressing limitations in current clinical methods.
AI.method: Used numerical experiments with a digital twin of the NEMA IEC phantom containing six spheres of varying diameters. Assessed quantitative accuracy using maximum recovery coefficient (RCmax) and analyzed convergence behavior, noise artifacts, and lesion preservation.
AI.result: OSEM shows unstable convergence requiring post-filtering, but underestimates small lesions and may lose them completely. MAP-Ent achieves stable convergence without filtering, preserves quantitative accuracy and contrast, but optimal iteration depends on a global regularization parameter.
AI.conclusion: MAP-Ent is superior for lesion quantification but needs locally adaptive regularization to achieve optimal performance across different lesion sizes, addressing the limitations of both approaches.

title: Spectral finite-element formulation of the optimized effective potential method for atomic structure in the random phase approximation
summary: We present a spectral finite-element formulation of the optimized effective potential (OEP) method for atomic structure calculations in the random phase approximation (RPA). In particular, we develop a finite-element framework that employs a polynomial mesh with element nodes placed according to the Chebyshev-Gauss-Lobatto scheme, high-order $\mathcal{C}^0$-continuous Lagrange polynomial basis functions, and Gauss-Legendre quadrature for spatial integration. We employ distinct polynomial degrees for the orbitals, Hartree potential, and RPA-OEP exchange-correlation potential. Through representative examples, we verify the accuracy of the developed framework, assess the fidelity of one-parameter double-hybrid functionals constructed with RPA correlation, and develop a machine-learned model for the RPA-OEP exchange-correlation potential at the level of the generalized gradient approximation, based on the kernel method and linear regression.

AI.tldr: Spectral finite-element formulation of optimized effective potential method for atomic RPA calculations with machine-learned exchange-correlation potential model.
AI.motivation: To develop an accurate computational framework for atomic structure calculations using the random phase approximation with optimized effective potentials, enabling high-fidelity electronic structure calculations.
AI.method: Spectral finite-element method with Chebyshev-Gauss-Lobatto mesh, high-order Lagrange basis functions, Gauss-Legendre quadrature, and distinct polynomial degrees for orbitals and potentials. Includes machine learning of exchange-correlation potentials using kernel methods.
AI.result: Accurate framework verification, assessment of double-hybrid functionals with RPA correlation, and development of machine-learned model for RPA-OEP exchange-correlation potential at GGA level.
AI.conclusion: The developed spectral finite-element framework provides accurate RPA-OEP calculations and enables machine learning of exchange-correlation potentials, advancing computational electronic structure methods.

title: High-Voltage Ionized Gas with Spherical Cathode Emission
summary: We consider a plasma that is created by a high voltage difference, which is known as a Townsend gas discharge. The plasma is confined to the region between two concentric spheres, one of which is a cathode and the other an anode. Ion-electron pairs are created by collisions inside the plasma. Additional electrons enter the plasma by collisions of ions with the cathode. We prove under certain conditions that there are many steady states exhibiting gas discharge, beginning with a `sparking' voltage. In fact, there is an analytic one-parameter family of them that connects the non-ionized gas to a plasma with arbitrarily high ionization or arbitrarily high potential, or else the family ends at an `anti-sparking' voltage.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes Townsend gas discharge between concentric spheres, proving existence of multiple steady states with sparking voltage thresholds.
AI.motivation: To mathematically characterize the steady states of Townsend gas discharge in spherical geometry, particularly understanding the transition from non-ionized gas to plasma discharge.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of plasma confined between concentric spheres (cathode and anode) with ion-electron pair creation via collisions and additional electrons from ion-cathode collisions. Mathematical proof under certain conditions.
AI.result: Existence of multiple steady states exhibiting gas discharge, starting at a 'sparking' voltage. There's an analytic one-parameter family connecting non-ionized gas to highly ionized plasma or high potential states, ending at an 'anti-sparking' voltage.
AI.conclusion: Townsend gas discharge in spherical geometry exhibits rich steady-state behavior with threshold voltages for sparking and anti-sparking, forming a continuum of possible plasma states.

title: H-mode transition in the TJ-II stellarator plasmas
summary: Since the first H-mode transitions were observed in TJ-II plasmas in 2008, an extensive experimental effort has been done aiming a better physics understanding of confinement transitions. In this paper, an overview of the main findings related to the L-H transition in TJ-II is presented including how the radial electric field is driven, which are the possible mechanisms for turbulence suppression, and what are the related temporal and spatial scales which can impact the transition. The trigger of the L-H transition in TJ-II plasmas is found to be more correlated with the development of fluctuating $E\times B$ flows than with steady-state $E_r$ effects, pointing to the role played by zonal flows in mediating the transition. Experimental evidence supporting the predator-prey relationship between turbulence and flows as the basis for the L-H transition, found for the first time in TJ-II, reinforces this conclusion. Besides, the reduction in the turbulent transport at the transition is detected at the barrier region but also in a wider radial range with weak or even zero $E\times B$ flow shear, what points to other mechanisms beyond the turbulence suppression by local sheared flows.

AI.tldr: TJ-II H-mode transition research shows L-H transition is triggered by fluctuating E×B flows (zonal flows) rather than steady-state Er, with predator-prey turbulence-flow dynamics and broader transport reduction beyond local shear suppression.
AI.motivation: To better understand the physics of confinement transitions (L-H transitions) in TJ-II plasmas, specifically investigating the driving mechanisms of radial electric field, turbulence suppression mechanisms, and relevant temporal/spatial scales affecting the transition.
AI.method: Experimental investigation of H-mode transitions in TJ-II plasmas, analyzing correlation between transition triggers and E×B flows, examining predator-prey relationship between turbulence and flows, and measuring turbulent transport reduction across radial ranges.
AI.result: L-H transition trigger correlates more with fluctuating E×B flows than steady-state Er effects, indicating zonal flow mediation. First experimental evidence of predator-prey turbulence-flow relationship in TJ-II. Turbulent transport reduction occurs both at barrier region and wider radial ranges with weak/zero E×B flow shear.
AI.conclusion: Zonal flows play key role in mediating L-H transitions through fluctuating E×B flows rather than steady-state effects. Turbulence suppression mechanisms extend beyond local sheared flows, suggesting additional physics at play in confinement transitions.

title: Local h-, p-, and k-Refinement Strategies for the Isogeometric Shifted Boundary Method Using THB-Splines
summary: The concept of trimming, embedding, or immersing geometries into a computational background mesh has gained considerable attention in recent years, particularly in isogeometric analysis (IGA). In this approach, the physical domain is represented independently from the computational mesh, allowing the latter to be generated more easily compared with body-fitted meshes. While this facilitates the treatment of complex geometries, it also introduces challenges, such as ill-conditioning of the stiffness matrix caused by small cut elements and difficulties in accurately enforcing boundary conditions. A recently proposed technique to address these issues is the Shifted Boundary Method (SBM), which represents the computational domain solely through uncut elements and enforces boundary conditions via a Taylor expansion from a surrogate boundary to the true boundary. Previous studies have shown that, for Neumann boundary conditions, the flux evaluation requires additional derivatives in the Taylor expansion, effectively reducing the order of convergence by one. In this work, we investigate for the first time the performance of SBM combined with Truncated Hierarchical B-splines (THB-splines) under various local refinement strategies. In particular, we propose local p- and k-refinement schemes for THB-splines and compare them with local h-refinement and the unmodified SBM. Furthermore, we propose an enhanced shift operator that incorporates mixed partial derivatives, in contrast to the standard operator. The study assesses accuracy, stability, and computational efficiency for benchmark problems on trimmed domains. The results highlight how different refinement strategies affect convergence behavior in trimmed IGA formulations using SBM and demonstrate that targeted degree elevation can mitigate the Neumann boundary limitations of the standard method.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the Shifted Boundary Method (SBM) combined with Truncated Hierarchical B-splines (THB-splines) for trimmed isogeometric analysis, proposing local p- and k-refinement schemes and an enhanced shift operator to address Neumann boundary limitations.
AI.motivation: Trimmed/immersed geometries in isogeometric analysis simplify mesh generation for complex domains but introduce challenges like ill-conditioning from small cut elements and difficulties in enforcing boundary conditions. The Shifted Boundary Method (SBM) addresses these issues but has limitations with Neumann boundary conditions where flux evaluation reduces convergence order.
AI.method: The study combines SBM with THB-splines and proposes: 1) local p- and k-refinement schemes for THB-splines, 2) comparison with local h-refinement and standard SBM, and 3) an enhanced shift operator incorporating mixed partial derivatives (unlike the standard operator).
AI.result: Results show how different refinement strategies affect convergence behavior in trimmed IGA with SBM. Targeted degree elevation (p-refinement) can mitigate the Neumann boundary limitations of the standard method, improving accuracy and stability for benchmark problems on trimmed domains.
AI.conclusion: The combination of SBM with THB-splines and appropriate local refinement strategies (particularly p-refinement) effectively addresses challenges in trimmed IGA. The enhanced shift operator and targeted degree elevation improve performance for Neumann boundary conditions, making the approach more robust for complex geometries.

title: Accurate atomic correlation and total energies for correlation consistent effective core potentials II: Rb-Xe elements
summary: We employ correlation-consistent effective core potentials (ccECPs) to perform exact or nearly exact correlation and total energy calculations for the fifth-row elements (Rb-Xe). Total energies are calculated using various correlated methods: configuration interaction (CI), coupled-cluster (CC) up to perturbative quadruple excitations whenever feasible, and stochastic quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) approaches. In order to estimate the energy at the complete basis set (CBS) limit, the basis sets are constructed systematically through aug-cc-p(C)VnZ for each ccECP and further extrapolated to the CBS limit within the corresponding methods. Kinetic energies are evaluated at the FCI/CISD level to provide insights into the electron density and localization of the ccECPs. We also provide data sets for widely used diffusion Monte Carlo (DMC) to quantify fixed-node biases with single-reference trial wavefunctions. These comprehensive benchmarks validate the accuracy of ccECPs within the CC, CI, and QMC methodologies, thus providing accurate and tested valence-only Hamiltonians for many-body electronic structure calculations.

AI.tldr: Benchmark study validates ccECPs for fifth-row elements using high-level correlated methods (CI, CC, QMC) with CBS extrapolation, providing accurate valence-only Hamiltonians for many-body calculations.
AI.motivation: To validate the accuracy of correlation-consistent effective core potentials (ccECPs) for fifth-row elements (Rb-Xe) through comprehensive benchmarking, providing reliable valence-only Hamiltonians for many-body electronic structure calculations.
AI.method: Used ccECPs with correlated methods (CI, CC up to perturbative quadruple excitations, QMC), systematically constructed basis sets (aug-cc-p(C)VnZ) with CBS extrapolation, evaluated kinetic energies at FCI/CISD level, and provided DMC datasets to quantify fixed-node biases.
AI.result: Comprehensive benchmarks validate ccECP accuracy within CC, CI, and QMC methodologies, providing accurate and tested valence-only Hamiltonians for many-body electronic structure calculations.
AI.conclusion: The study successfully validates ccECPs for fifth-row elements, establishing them as accurate valence-only Hamiltonians suitable for high-level correlated electronic structure calculations across multiple methodologies.

title: First Eigenvalue and Torsional Rigidity: Isoperimetric Inequalities for the Fractional Laplacian
summary: We present a fractional counterpart of a generalized Kohler-Jobin inequality, showing that, among all bounded, open sets $Ω\subset \mathbb{R}^N$ with Lipschitz boundary, having the same fractional torsional rigidity, the first Dirichlet eigenvalue $λ_1(Ω)$ of the fractional Laplacian attains its minimum on balls. With the same arguments we also establish a reverse Hölder inequality for an eigenfunction corresponding to $λ_1(Ω)$.

AI.tldr: The paper proves a fractional version of the Kohler-Jobin inequality, showing that among sets with equal fractional torsional rigidity, balls minimize the first Dirichlet eigenvalue of the fractional Laplacian.
AI.motivation: To extend classical geometric inequalities involving eigenvalues and torsional rigidity to the fractional setting, establishing extremal properties of balls for fractional operators.
AI.method: Uses fractional calculus and geometric analysis techniques to prove a fractional Kohler-Jobin inequality, applying similar arguments to establish a reverse Hölder inequality for eigenfunctions.
AI.result: Proves that among bounded open sets with Lipschitz boundary having equal fractional torsional rigidity, balls minimize the first Dirichlet eigenvalue of the fractional Laplacian.
AI.conclusion: The work establishes fundamental geometric inequalities in the fractional context, confirming the extremal role of balls for fractional eigenvalue problems with torsional rigidity constraints.

title: Characteristic features of the resonant trident process in the field of a strong monochromatic electromagnetic wave
summary: The characteristic features of the resonant trident process (Oleinik resonances) have been theoretically studied in a wide range of frequencies and intensities of a circularly polarized strong electromagnetic wave. The resonant trident process is defined by two characteristic quantum energies: the characteristic energy of the nonlinear Compton effect and the characteristic energy of the nonlinear Breit-Wheeler process. These characteristic energies depend significantly on the frequency and intensity of the wave, as well as on the angle between the momenta of the initial electrons and the electromagnetic wave. The resonant trident process is effective when the energy of the initial electrons is greater than or on the order of magnitude of the corresponding characteristic energies. It is shown that quantum entanglement of final particles takes place in this resonant process. An important aspect of the resonant trident process is the equality of the energies of the electron and positron pairs. Analytical expressions for the differential rates of the resonant trident process on the energy of final particles are obtained. The corresponding analytical expressions for full rates have also been obtained. It is shown that the rate data of the resonant trident process in the field of optical and X-ray wave frequencies significantly exceed the corresponding rate of the non-resonant trident process. Results obtained can be used in experiments at leading laser centers, as well as to explain QED processes in strong X-ray fields near neutron stars and magnetars.

AI.tldr: Theoretical study of resonant trident process (Oleinik resonances) in strong electromagnetic fields shows enhanced rates compared to non-resonant process, with quantum entanglement of final particles and equal electron-positron pair energies.
AI.motivation: To understand the resonant trident process in strong electromagnetic fields across different frequency and intensity ranges, and to provide analytical tools for experiments at laser facilities and astrophysical applications near neutron stars and magnetars.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of resonant trident process using characteristic quantum energies (nonlinear Compton and Breit-Wheeler energies) that depend on wave frequency, intensity, and angle between initial electron momenta and wave. Analytical derivation of differential and full rates.
AI.result: Resonant trident process is effective when initial electron energy exceeds characteristic energies. Quantum entanglement occurs in final particles. Rates for optical and X-ray frequencies significantly exceed non-resonant process rates. Analytical expressions for differential and full rates obtained.
AI.conclusion: Resonant trident process is important for strong-field QED experiments at laser facilities and astrophysical phenomena near neutron stars/magnetars, with enhanced rates and quantum entanglement features providing new experimental signatures.

title: Study of a TPFA scheme for the stochastic Allen-Cahn equation with constraint though numerical experiments
summary: This contribution provides numerical experiments for a finite volume scheme for an approximation of the stochastic Allen-Cahn equation with homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions. The approximation is done by a Yosida approximation of the subdifferential operator. The problem is set on a polygonal bounded domain in two or three dimensions. The non-linear character of the projection term induces challenges to implement the scheme. To this end, we provide a splitting method for the finite volume scheme. We show that the splitting method is accurate. The computational error estimates induce that the squared $L^2$-error w.r.t. time is of order $1$ as long as the noise term is small enough. For larger noise terms the order of convergence w.r.t. time might become worse.

AI.tldr: Numerical experiments for a finite volume scheme approximating stochastic Allen-Cahn equation with Neumann boundary conditions using Yosida approximation and splitting method.
AI.motivation: To develop and test a numerical scheme for the stochastic Allen-Cahn equation with homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions, addressing challenges from the nonlinear projection term in the subdifferential operator approximation.
AI.method: Finite volume scheme with Yosida approximation of the subdifferential operator, implemented using a splitting method to handle the nonlinear projection term on polygonal bounded domains in 2D/3D.
AI.result: The splitting method is shown to be accurate. Computational error estimates indicate squared L²-error with respect to time is of order 1 for small noise terms, but convergence order may degrade for larger noise terms.
AI.conclusion: The proposed finite volume scheme with splitting method provides an effective numerical approach for stochastic Allen-Cahn equations, though convergence properties depend on noise magnitude.

title: Numerical study of Lagrangian velocity structure functions using acceleration statistics and a spatial-temporal perspective
summary: A fundamental relation in Lagrangian Kolmogorov theory is concerned with inertial range scaling of the second-order velocity structure function over intermediate time lags at sufficiently high Reynolds numbers. However, the scaling is not well observed, and it is uncertain whether the scaling constant ($C_0$) truly approaches a constant value at asymptotic Reynolds numbers. In this paper, direct numerical simulation of forced isotropic turbulence at Taylor-scale Reynolds numbers between 140 and 1300 is used to help advance understanding in this subject. Uncertainties arising from modest simulation time spans are addressed by expressing the velocity structure function in terms of the acceleration autocorrelation, which suggests that $C_0$ may be sensitive to intermittency effects, leading to a sustained, although weak, Reynolds number dependence. The Lagrangian velocity increment is examined from a spatial-temporal perspective, as a combination of convective (spatial) and local (temporal) contributions, which are subject to a strong but incomplete mutual cancellation dependent on Reynolds number and time lag. The convective increment is strongly influenced by the particle displacement, which is driven by large-scale dynamics and can thus grow into inertial range dimensions in space within just a few Kolmogorov time scales, without fully satisfying classical Lagrangian inertial-range requirements. An overall conclusion in this work is that both the limited range of time scales (narrower than for length scales) and the effects of particle displacements have significant roles in the observed behavior of the second-order Lagrangian velocity structure function.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates why the classical Lagrangian inertial-range scaling of second-order velocity structure functions is not well observed in simulations, finding that limited time scales and particle displacement effects significantly influence the behavior.
AI.motivation: The classical Lagrangian Kolmogorov theory predicts inertial-range scaling for second-order velocity structure functions, but this scaling is not well observed in practice, and it's uncertain whether the scaling constant C₀ truly approaches a constant at asymptotic Reynolds numbers.
AI.method: Direct numerical simulation of forced isotropic turbulence at Taylor-scale Reynolds numbers between 140 and 1300, with analysis of velocity structure functions expressed in terms of acceleration autocorrelation, and examination of Lagrangian velocity increments from spatial-temporal perspectives separating convective and local contributions.
AI.result: C₀ shows sensitivity to intermittency effects with sustained weak Reynolds number dependence; convective contributions are strongly influenced by particle displacements that can grow into inertial range dimensions quickly; there's strong but incomplete mutual cancellation between convective and local contributions dependent on Reynolds number and time lag.
AI.conclusion: Both the limited range of time scales (narrower than for length scales) and the effects of particle displacements play significant roles in the observed behavior of second-order Lagrangian velocity structure functions, explaining why classical scaling is not well observed.

title: On the subcritical Lane-Emden equation on Riemannian models with polynomial volume growth
summary:
We focus on the problems of existence and non-existence of positive solutions for the Sobolev-subcritical Lane-Emden equation on certain Riemannian manifolds (mainly models) with asymptotically negative curvature, which, from the viewpoint of the volume growth of geodesic balls, can be regarded as intermediate settings between the Euclidean and the hyperbolic spaces.
  A number of interesting phenomena arise: the subcritical regime naturally divides into three further ranges, characterized by existence phenomena (slightly subcritical), non-existence phenomena (strongly subcritical), and by a mixed behavior where existence and non-existence strongly depend on additional assumptions on the manifold (intermediate). In the intermediate regime, we further show that the radial homogeneous Dirichlet problem in geodesics balls may admit multiple positive solutions, thereby revealing substantial differences with respect to both the Euclidean and the hyperbolic settings.

AI.tldr: The paper studies existence and non-existence of positive solutions for Sobolev-subcritical Lane-Emden equations on Riemannian manifolds with asymptotically negative curvature, revealing three distinct subcritical regimes with different solution behaviors.
AI.motivation: To understand how the geometry of Riemannian manifolds with asymptotically negative curvature affects the existence of positive solutions to Lane-Emden equations, particularly in intermediate settings between Euclidean and hyperbolic spaces.
AI.method: Analysis of Sobolev-subcritical Lane-Emden equations on certain Riemannian manifolds (mainly models) with asymptotically negative curvature, examining the volume growth of geodesic balls and studying the radial homogeneous Dirichlet problem in geodesic balls.
AI.result: Three distinct subcritical regimes emerge: slightly subcritical (existence phenomena), strongly subcritical (non-existence phenomena), and intermediate (mixed behavior dependent on manifold assumptions). In the intermediate regime, multiple positive solutions may exist for radial homogeneous Dirichlet problems in geodesic balls.
AI.conclusion: The geometry of manifolds with asymptotically negative curvature creates rich solution behaviors for Lane-Emden equations, with substantial differences from both Euclidean and hyperbolic settings, particularly in the intermediate regime where multiple solutions can exist.

title: Doppler-induced continuous spectral broadening of ultraviolet lasers
summary: We propose a compact scheme based on ultrafast-rotating phase plates (URPPs) to achieve continuous spectral broadening of ultraviolet lasers. The rapid rotation elements behave as a random oscillator which induces Doppler frequency shift into the ultraviolet lasers. As an example, for a disk-shaped phase plate, with the beam acting on the edge at a radius of 10 cm, a rotation frequency of 1 kHz, and a phase-element size of 10 nm, the continuous spectral broadening reaches 0.07%. Further increasing the rotation speed or reducing the phase-element can lead to greater spectral broadening. When multiple URPPs are arranged in series, the superimposed spatiotemporal modulation further enhances the continuous spectral broadening and achieves more effective speckle smoothing. The scheme is applicable to broadening the independent spectrum of optical frequency combs as well as to the mitigation of laser-plasma instabilities in inertial fusion energy.

AI.tldr: Ultrafast-rotating phase plates (URPPs) enable continuous spectral broadening of UV lasers through Doppler frequency shifts, with potential applications in optical frequency combs and inertial fusion energy.
AI.motivation: To develop a compact method for continuous spectral broadening of ultraviolet lasers, which is needed for applications like optical frequency combs and mitigating laser-plasma instabilities in inertial fusion energy.
AI.method: Using ultrafast-rotating phase plates (URPPs) that act as random oscillators to induce Doppler frequency shifts in UV lasers. The scheme involves rotating phase plates (disk-shaped with beam acting at the edge), and can be enhanced by arranging multiple URPPs in series for superimposed spatiotemporal modulation.
AI.result: With a disk-shaped phase plate (10 cm radius, 1 kHz rotation, 10 nm phase-element size), continuous spectral broadening reaches 0.07%. Higher rotation speeds or smaller phase-elements yield greater broadening. Multiple URPPs in series further enhance spectral broadening and improve speckle smoothing.
AI.conclusion: The URPP scheme provides an effective approach for continuous spectral broadening of UV lasers, with promising applications in optical frequency comb broadening and laser-plasma instability mitigation for inertial fusion energy.

title: Preconditioning for the high-order sampling of the invariant distribution of parabolic semilinear SPDEs
summary: For a class of ergodic parabolic semilinear stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs) with gradient structure, we introduce a preconditioning technique and design high-order integrators for the approximation of the invariant distribution. The preconditioning yields improved temporal regularity of the dynamics while preserving the invariant distribution and allows the application of postprocessed integrators. For the semilinear heat equation driven by space-time white noise in dimension $1$, we obtain new temporal integrators with orders $1$ and $2$ for sampling the invariant distribution with a minor overcost compared to the standard semilinear implicit Euler method of order $1/2$. Numerical experiments confirm the theoretical findings and illustrate the efficiency of the approach.

AI.tldr: Preconditioning technique enables high-order integrators for sampling invariant distribution of gradient SPDEs, achieving orders 1 and 2 vs standard 1/2 order.
AI.motivation: Standard methods for sampling invariant distributions of ergodic parabolic semilinear SPDEs with gradient structure have low order (1/2), motivating development of higher-order integrators for more efficient sampling.
AI.method: Introduces preconditioning technique that improves temporal regularity while preserving invariant distribution, enabling application of postprocessed integrators. Specifically applied to semilinear heat equation driven by space-time white noise in 1D.
AI.result: Develops new temporal integrators with orders 1 and 2 for sampling invariant distribution, with only minor overcost compared to standard semilinear implicit Euler method of order 1/2.
AI.conclusion: Preconditioning enables efficient high-order sampling of invariant distributions for gradient SPDEs, with numerical experiments confirming theoretical findings and demonstrating approach efficiency.

title: Full-Wave Optical Modeling of Leaf Internal Light Scattering Dynamics with Potential Applications for Early Detection of Foliar Fungal Disease
summary: Light interacting with plant leaves undergoes reflection, transmission, scattering, and absorption, which together determine leaf optical properties. Changes in leaf architecture disrupt internal light scattering dynamics and consequently affect photosynthetic performance. Previous studies on internal leaf light scattering have primarily relied on ray-tracing approaches (e.g., Raytran) or radiative-transfer models (e.g., PROSPECT). However, these high-frequency approximations cannot capture diffraction and coherent multiple scattering in wavelength-scale leaf tissues, unlike full-wave electromagnetic simulations. Here, we employ GPU-accelerated Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) simulations to model internal light scattering dynamics using segmented cross-section image geometries of representative dicot and monocot leaves with wavelength-dependent complex refractive indices. The simulations accurately reproduce the reflectance and transmittance characteristics of healthy leaves, showing strong agreement with the PROSPECT model, with average Lin's concordance values of 0.8962 for dicot leaves and 0.7849 for monocot leaves. We further simulate early-stage necrotrophic fungal infection by modeling melanized hyphae penetrating the cuticle and upper epidermis. Diseased leaves exhibit a pronounced reduction in visible green reflectance and a marked suppression of the near-infrared reflectance plateau, consistent with experimental observations. Remaining discrepancies in the visible band are expected to be reduced through more advanced geometric and material modeling. This proof-of-concept study presents a full-wave FDTD optical modeling framework for plant-leaf light scattering, enabling physics-based analysis of internal scattering before and after early-stage fungal penetration and supporting the use of light scattering as an indicator for pre-symptomatic plant fungal disease detection.

AI.tldr: GPU-accelerated FDTD simulations model leaf light scattering at wavelength scale, reproducing reflectance/transmittance of healthy leaves and showing reduced reflectance in early fungal infection.
AI.motivation: Existing ray-tracing and radiative-transfer models cannot capture diffraction and coherent multiple scattering in wavelength-scale leaf tissues, unlike full-wave electromagnetic simulations needed for accurate optical modeling.
AI.method: GPU-accelerated Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) simulations using segmented cross-section image geometries of dicot/monocot leaves with wavelength-dependent complex refractive indices, modeling both healthy leaves and early-stage fungal infection with melanized hyphae.
AI.result: Simulations accurately reproduce reflectance/transmittance of healthy leaves (Lin's concordance: 0.8962 dicot, 0.7849 monocot). Diseased leaves show reduced visible green reflectance and suppressed near-infrared plateau, consistent with experiments.
AI.conclusion: Proof-of-concept full-wave FDTD optical modeling framework enables physics-based analysis of leaf light scattering, supporting use of light scattering as indicator for pre-symptomatic plant fungal disease detection.

title: Solutions of the thin film equation obtained in the limit of vanishing slip
summary: We analyze the evolution of thin liquid droplets in the lubrication approximation with different slip conditions at the liquid-solid interface. Motivated by the classical no-slip paradox which states that the Navier-Stokes equations with a no-slip boundary condition require unphysical infinite dissipation during droplet spreading, we focus on the limit of vanishing slip. We show that in the no-slip limit three fundamentally different classes of limiting solutions are approached, each of them corresponding to a different scaling of the microscopic contact angle as the regularization parameter vanishes. These findings suggest that the thin-film equation with no slip supports a rich family of physically admissible solutions, provided one interprets the no-slip thin film equation as the asymptotic limit of models which regularized slip conditions. Even though the large apparent contact angles in some of these solutions seem incompatible with the lubrication approximation, a refined analysis shows that the underlying physical variables remain consistent with the assumptions for the lubrication approximation.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes thin liquid droplet evolution with different slip conditions, focusing on the no-slip limit paradox and showing three distinct classes of limiting solutions emerge from different microscopic contact angle scalings.
AI.motivation: The motivation stems from the classical no-slip paradox in fluid dynamics, where the Navier-Stokes equations with no-slip boundary conditions require infinite dissipation during droplet spreading, which is physically unrealistic. The authors aim to understand how to properly interpret the no-slip limit in thin-film equations.
AI.method: The authors analyze thin liquid droplets using the lubrication approximation with different slip conditions at the liquid-solid interface. They focus on the limit of vanishing slip and examine how different scalings of the microscopic contact angle as the regularization parameter vanishes lead to different limiting solutions.
AI.result: The analysis reveals three fundamentally different classes of limiting solutions in the no-slip limit, each corresponding to a different scaling of the microscopic contact angle as the slip regularization parameter vanishes. This shows that the thin-film equation with no slip supports a rich family of physically admissible solutions when interpreted as the asymptotic limit of models with regularized slip conditions.
AI.conclusion: The no-slip thin film equation can be properly interpreted as the asymptotic limit of models with regularized slip conditions, supporting multiple physically admissible solutions. Even though some solutions appear to have large apparent contact angles that seem incompatible with the lubrication approximation, a refined analysis shows the underlying physical variables remain consistent with the lubrication assumptions.

title: Convergence rates for a finite volume scheme of a stochastic non-linear parabolic equation
summary: In this contribution, we provide convergence rates for a finite volume scheme of a stochastic non-linear parabolic equation with multiplicative Lipschitz noise and homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions. More precisely, we give an error estimate for the $L^2$-norm of the space-time discretization by a semi-implicit Euler scheme with respect to time and a two-point flux approximation finite volume scheme with respect to space and the variational solution. The only regularity assumptions additionally needed is spatial regularity of the initial datum and smoothness of the diffusive term.

AI.tldr: Convergence rates for finite volume scheme of stochastic nonlinear parabolic PDE with multiplicative Lipschitz noise and Neumann boundary conditions.
AI.motivation: To provide rigorous error estimates for numerical discretization of stochastic nonlinear parabolic equations, which are important in modeling various physical phenomena with random perturbations.
AI.method: Semi-implicit Euler scheme for time discretization combined with two-point flux approximation finite volume scheme for space discretization. Analysis focuses on L²-norm error estimates between the numerical solution and variational solution.
AI.result: Convergence rates established for the finite volume scheme under minimal regularity assumptions: spatial regularity of initial datum and smoothness of diffusive term.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides rigorous convergence analysis for numerical approximation of stochastic nonlinear parabolic equations with multiplicative noise, establishing error estimates for combined space-time discretization using finite volume methods.

title: An Asymptotic Approach for Modeling Multiscale Complex Fluids at the Fast Relaxation Limit
summary: We present a new asymptotic strategy for general micro-macro models which analyze complex viscoelastic fluids governed by coupled multiscale dynamics. In such models, the elastic stress appearing in the macroscopic continuum equation is derived from the microscopic kinetic theory, which makes direct numerical simulations computationally expensive. To address this challenge, we introduce a formal asymptotic scheme that expands the density function around an equilibrium distribution, thereby reducing the high computational cost associated with the fully coupled microscopic processes while still maintaining the dynamic microscopic feedback in explicit expressions. The proposed asymptotic expansion is based on a detailed physical scaling law which characterizes the multiscale balance at the fast relaxation limit of the microscopic state. An asymptotic closure model for the macroscopic fluid equation is then derived according to the explicit asymptotic density expansion. Furthermore, the resulting closure model preserves the energy-dissipation law inherited from the original fully coupled multiscale system. Numerical experiments are performed to validate the asymptotic density formula and the corresponding flow velocity equations in several micro-macro models. This new asymptotic strategy offers a promising approach for efficient computations of a wide range of multiscale complex fluids.

AI.tldr: A new asymptotic strategy for efficient computation of micro-macro viscoelastic fluid models by expanding density around equilibrium to reduce computational cost while preserving multiscale dynamics.
AI.motivation: Direct numerical simulations of micro-macro models for complex viscoelastic fluids are computationally expensive due to coupled multiscale dynamics where elastic stress in macroscopic equations comes from microscopic kinetic theory.
AI.method: Introduces a formal asymptotic scheme that expands the density function around an equilibrium distribution based on detailed physical scaling laws characterizing multiscale balance at fast relaxation limit. Derives asymptotic closure model for macroscopic fluid equations from explicit asymptotic density expansion.
AI.result: The asymptotic closure model preserves the energy-dissipation law from the original multiscale system. Numerical experiments validate the asymptotic density formula and flow velocity equations in several micro-macro models.
AI.conclusion: The asymptotic strategy offers a promising approach for efficient computations of a wide range of multiscale complex fluids by reducing computational costs while maintaining microscopic feedback.

title: Solution concepts for a model of visco-elasto-plasticity with slight compressibility
summary: We study a model for the deformation of a visco-elasto-plastic material that is nearly incompressible. It originates from geophysics, is given in the Eulerian description and combines a Kelvin-Voigt rheology in the spherical part with a Jeffreys-type rheology in the deviatoric part. Despite a constant density, the model allows for non-isochoric deformation and the propagation of pressure waves. An additive decomposition of the strain rate into elastic and inelastic parts leads to an evolution equation for the small elastic strain, which is coupled with an adapted momentum equation. As plasticity is modeled through a non-smooth dissipation potential, we introduce a weak formulation in terms of a variational inequality. Since the well-posedness in such a weak setting is out of reach, we study two possible modifications: the regularization in terms of stress diffusion, and the relaxation of the solvability concept by transition to energy-variational solutions. In both cases, solutions are constructed by the same time-discrete scheme, consisting of solving a saddle-point problem in each time step.

AI.tldr: This paper studies a visco-elasto-plastic material model for nearly incompressible geophysical materials, combining Kelvin-Voigt and Jeffreys-type rheologies with non-isochoric deformation despite constant density.
AI.motivation: The model originates from geophysics and addresses the need to understand deformation of nearly incompressible materials that exhibit visco-elasto-plastic behavior, allowing for non-isochoric deformation and pressure wave propagation even with constant density.
AI.method: The authors use an additive decomposition of strain rate into elastic and inelastic parts, leading to an evolution equation for small elastic strain coupled with an adapted momentum equation. Plasticity is modeled through a non-smooth dissipation potential, requiring a weak formulation as a variational inequality. Two modifications are studied: stress diffusion regularization and energy-variational solutions relaxation.
AI.result: Solutions are constructed using a time-discrete scheme that solves a saddle-point problem in each time step. The paper develops mathematical frameworks for both regularization and relaxation approaches to handle the non-smooth plasticity model.
AI.conclusion: The paper presents mathematical formulations for visco-elasto-plastic materials with nearly incompressible behavior, addressing the challenges of non-smooth dissipation potentials through regularization and relaxation approaches, with practical solution methods using time-discrete saddle-point problems.

title: A Short Report on Importance Sampling for Rare Event Simulation in Diffusions
summary: In this manuscript, we investigate importance sampling methods for rare-event simulation in diffusion processes. We show, from a large-deviation perspective, that the resulting importance sampling estimator is log-efficient. This connection is established via a stochastic optimal control formulation, and the associated Hamilton--Jacobi--Bellman (HJB) equation is derived using dynamic programming. To approximate the optimal control, we adopt a spectral parameterization and employ the cross-entropy method to estimate the parameters by solving a least-squares problem. Finally, we present a numerical example to validate the effectiveness of the cross-entropy approach and the efficiency of the resulting importance sampling estimator.

AI.tldr: Importance sampling for rare-event simulation in diffusions is log-efficient via stochastic optimal control, with cross-entropy method for parameter estimation.
AI.motivation: To develop efficient importance sampling methods for rare-event simulation in diffusion processes, addressing the computational challenges of estimating rare events.
AI.method: Stochastic optimal control formulation with HJB equation, spectral parameterization for optimal control approximation, and cross-entropy method for parameter estimation via least-squares.
AI.result: The importance sampling estimator is proven to be log-efficient from a large-deviation perspective, and numerical validation confirms effectiveness of the cross-entropy approach.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework successfully connects importance sampling with stochastic optimal control, providing an efficient method for rare-event simulation in diffusion processes.

title: Magnetic, Structural, and Electronic Properties of CrOCl with the PBE Functional
summary: CrOCl is a van der Waals-layered insulator with an antiferromagnetic ground state, making it a promising platform for exfoliation and the exploration of low-dimensional magnetism. An accurate ab initio description is therefore essential. Previous density-functional studies have shown that DFT+$U$ calculations may erroneously favor ferromagnetic order depending on the choice of parametrization, an issue that cannot be remedied by simply adjusting the value of $U$. Here, we demonstrate that an explicit Hubbard correction is unnecessary: the PBE functional correctly reproduces the AFM ground state while simultaneously improving the description of structural properties. Moreover, PBE provides a reliable account of the electronic structure. These findings clarify the role of correlation effects in CrOCl and identify PBE as a robust starting point for future ab initio studies of CrOCl-based materials.

AI.tldr: PBE functional correctly predicts CrOCl's antiferromagnetic ground state without Hubbard U correction, outperforming DFT+U approaches that sometimes erroneously favor ferromagnetism.
AI.motivation: CrOCl is a van der Waals-layered antiferromagnetic insulator important for low-dimensional magnetism studies, but previous DFT+U calculations gave inconsistent magnetic ground states depending on parametrization choices.
AI.method: Using PBE functional without explicit Hubbard U correction to study CrOCl's magnetic ordering, structural properties, and electronic structure compared to DFT+U approaches.
AI.result: PBE correctly reproduces the antiferromagnetic ground state, improves structural property descriptions, and provides reliable electronic structure without the need for Hubbard corrections that can introduce errors.
AI.conclusion: Correlation effects in CrOCl are adequately captured by PBE, making it a robust starting point for future ab initio studies of CrOCl-based materials without the complications of DFT+U parametrization.

title: A quantitative Hopf-Oleinik lemma for degenerate fully nonlinear operators and applications to free boundary problems
summary: We prove a quantitative inhomogeneous Hopf-Oleinik lemma for viscosity solutions of $$|\nabla u|^αF(D^{2}u)=f $$ and, more generally, for viscosity supersolutions of $|\nabla u|^α\,{M}^-_{λ,Λ}(D^{2}u)\le f$. The result yields linear boundary growth with universal constants depending only on the structural data. We also exhibit a counterexample showing that the Hopf lemma fails for equations that act only in the large-gradient regime (in the sense of Imbert and Silvestre), thereby delineating the scope of our theorem. As applications, we obtain Lipschitz regularity for viscosity solutions of one-phase Bernoulli free boundary problems driven by these degenerate fully nonlinear operators and derive $\varepsilon$-uniform Lipschitz bounds for a one-phase flame propagation model.

AI.tldr: Quantitative inhomogeneous Hopf-Oleinik lemma for degenerate fully nonlinear PDEs with gradient-dependent diffusion, with applications to free boundary problems.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to establish boundary regularity results for degenerate fully nonlinear elliptic equations where the diffusion coefficient depends on the gradient magnitude. Such equations arise in various applications including free boundary problems and flame propagation models, but existing Hopf lemma results are limited for these degenerate operators.
AI.method: The authors prove a quantitative inhomogeneous Hopf-Oleinik lemma for viscosity solutions of equations like |∇u|^αF(D²u)=f and more generally for supersolutions of |∇u|^αM⁻_{λ,Λ}(D²u)≤f. They use viscosity solution techniques and provide a counterexample showing the lemma fails for equations acting only in the large-gradient regime (Imbert-Silvestre type operators).
AI.result: The main result yields linear boundary growth with universal constants depending only on structural data. Applications include Lipschitz regularity for viscosity solutions of one-phase Bernoulli free boundary problems driven by these operators, and ε-uniform Lipschitz bounds for a one-phase flame propagation model.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes boundary regularity for a class of degenerate fully nonlinear elliptic equations, delineating the scope of applicability through a counterexample, and demonstrates the utility of these results in free boundary problems and flame propagation models.

title: On General Linearly Implicit Quantized State System Methods
summary: This work proposes a methodology to develop new numerical integration algorithms for ordinary differential equations based on state quantization, generalizing the notions of Linearly Implicit Quantized State Systems (LIQSS) methods. Using this idea, two novel sub-families of algorithms are designed that improve the performance of current LIQSS methods while preserving their properties regarding stability, global error bound and efficient event handling capabilities. The features of the new algorithms are studied in two application examples where the advantages over classic numerical integration algorithms is also analyzed.

AI.tldr: Proposes new numerical integration algorithms for ODEs using state quantization, generalizing LIQSS methods with improved performance while preserving stability and error properties.
AI.motivation: To develop improved numerical integration algorithms that maintain the benefits of LIQSS methods (stability, global error bounds, efficient event handling) while enhancing computational performance.
AI.method: Uses state quantization methodology to generalize LIQSS methods, designing two novel sub-families of algorithms based on this quantization approach.
AI.result: Two new algorithm sub-families that improve performance over current LIQSS methods while preserving stability, global error bounds, and efficient event handling capabilities.
AI.conclusion: The proposed quantization-based methodology successfully generates improved numerical integration algorithms that outperform classic methods while maintaining desirable LIQSS properties, as demonstrated in application examples.

title: Estimating Spatially Resolved Radiation Fields Using Neural Networks
summary: We present an in-depth analysis on how to build and train neural networks to estimate the spatial distribution of scattered radiation fields for radiation protection dosimetry in medical radiation fields, such as those found in Interventional Radiology and Cardiology. Therefore, we present three different synthetically generated datasets with increasing complexity for training, using a Monte-Carlo Simulation application based on Geant4. On those datasets, we evaluate convolutional and fully connected architectures of neural networks to demonstrate which design decisions work well for reconstructing the fluence and spectra distributions over the spatial domain of such radiation fields. All used datasets as well as our training pipeline are published as open source in separate repositories.
